subject: history
title: Revolutionary Activities Timeline (1908-1917)
description: Chronological sequence of major revolutionary incidents and government responses

phases.name: Peak Revolutionary Activity
phases.description: Height of revolutionary terrorism in Bengal and Maharashtra

phases.name: International Revolutionary Phase
phases.description: Focus shifts to overseas revolutionary activities

phases.name: World War I Conspiracies
phases.description: Revolutionary attempts to exploit British involvement in WWI

events.title: Explosive Substances Act
events.description: British pass harsh law against bomb-making

points: Passed after series of bomb incidents
Made possession or manufacture of explosives punishable by death
Gave police extensive search powers
First major anti-terrorist legislation
details.significance: Marked beginning of systematic legal repression

events.title: Muzaffarpur Bomb (Alipore Bomb Conspiracy)
events.description: Khudiram Bose and Prafulla Chaki attempt to kill Magistrate Kingsford

points: Target: Magistrate Kingsford (harsh on nationalists)
Bomb thrown at wrong carriage
Two British ladies (Kennedy family) killed
Prafulla Chaki shot himself to avoid arrest
Khudiram Bose (18) arrested, tried, hanged (Aug 11, 1908)
Massive public sympathy for Khudiram
Led to Alipore Bomb Conspiracy Case
details.significance: Youngest martyr; exposed revolutionary network in Bengal
details.trial: 34 accused including Aurobindo Ghosh; C.R. Das defended; Aurobindo acquitted

points: Targeted revolutionary publications like Jugantar, Sandhya
Allowed confiscation of printing presses
Editors could be imprisoned without trial
Many newspapers shut down or went underground

events.title: Murder of Curzon Wyllie
events.description: Madan Lal Dhingra assassinates British official in London

points: Location: Imperial Institute, London
Victim: Sir William Hutt Curzon Wyllie (Political ADC to Secretary of State)
Assassin: Madan Lal Dhingra (Punjabi revolutionary, India House member)
Also killed: Dr. Cawas Lalcaca (Parsi doctor who tried to intervene)
Dhingra caught on spot
Refused to apologize; gave defiant statement
Hanged on August 17, 1909, Pentonville Prison, London
details.statement: Dhingra's famous statement: I believe the only lesson required in India is to learn to die, and the only way to teach it is by dying ourselves
details.significance: Revolutionary terrorism reached London; shocked British establishment
details.aftermath: India House closed; Savarkar and others became suspects

events.title: Murder of Collector Jackson
events.description: Anant Laxman Kanhere kills Nasik Collector during play

points: Location: Vijayanand Theatre, Nasik (during play performance)
Victim: Arthur Mason Tippetts Jackson (District Collector)
Assassin: Anant Laxman Kanhere (inspired by Savarkar's teachings)
Jackson was harsh on nationalists and demeaning towards Indians
Kanhere shot Jackson at point-blank range
Made no attempt to escape
Tried and hanged on April 19, 1910
details.connection: V.D. Savarkar implicated; arrested in London (March 1910)
details.significance: Led to Savarkar's arrest and Nashik Conspiracy Case

events.title: V.D. Savarkar Arrested in London
events.description: Revolutionary leader arrested and brought to India for trial

points: Arrested in London in connection with Jackson murder
Attempted dramatic escape while ship docked at Marseilles, France (July 1910)
Swam to French shore but captured and returned (international controversy)
Tried in India for Nashik Conspiracy Case
Sentenced to two life imprisonments (50 years total)
Transported to Cellular Jail, Andaman (Kalapani)
Remained imprisoned till 1921; restrictions till 1937
details.significance: Removed most influential revolutionary ideologue; dampened Maharashtra revolutionary movement

points: Required newspapers to deposit security
Security forfeited if seditious content published
Local government could ban newspapers
Particularly targeted revolutionary publications

events.title: Delhi Conspiracy - Bomb on Viceroy Hardinge
events.description: Attempt to assassinate Viceroy during Delhi Durbar entry

points: Occasion: Viceroy Hardinge's state entry into new capital Delhi
Delhi Durbar celebration (capital shift from Calcutta to Delhi)
Bomb thrown at Viceroy's howdah (elephant seat)
Conspirators: Rash Behari Bose (mastermind), Basanta Kumar Biswas (thrower)
Viceroy seriously injured but survived
Attendant killed, Vicereine injured
Basanta Kumar Biswas arrested and hanged (May 1915)
Rash Behari Bose escaped; remained underground
details.significance: Boldest attack on highest British authority in India; showed revolutionary reach
details.aftermath: Massive manhunt; many arrested; revolutionary movement severely weakened

events.title: Ghadar Party Founded
events.description: Revolutionary organization formed in San Francisco by Indian immigrants

points: Founded in San Francisco, California, USA
Key founders: Lala Har Dayal, Sohan Singh Bhakna, Kartar Singh Sarabha
Membership: Mainly Punjabi Sikh immigrants (also some Muslims, Hindus)
Newspaper: 'Ghadar' (meaning Mutiny) in Urdu, Punjabi, Hindi
Ideology: Complete independence through armed revolution
Slogan: 'Angrezi Raj ka Dushman' (Enemy of British Rule)
Commemorated 1857 Revolt
Collected funds and arms for uprising in India
details.significance: First organized overseas revolutionary movement; international dimension to freedom struggle

events.title: World War I Begins
events.description: Revolutionaries see British vulnerability as opportunity

points: Britain declares war on Germany (August 4, 1914)
India automatically at war (as British colony)
British forces stretched thin globally
Revolutionaries adopted 'enemy's enemy is friend' policy
Sought German, Turkish, and Afghan support
Ghadar Party members decided to return to India
Plan: Incite mutiny in Indian Army
details.significance: WWI seen as golden opportunity for revolution; led to multiple conspiracies

events.title: Ghadar Uprising Attempt
events.description: Planned simultaneous mutiny in Punjab military regiments fails

points: About 8,000 Ghadarites returned to India (1914-1915)
Plan: Simultaneous mutiny in multiple regiments (Feb 21, 1915)
Coordinated by Rash Behari Bose and Ghadar Party
Target regiments: 23rd Cavalry (Lahore), 26th Punjab Regiment, others
Plan exposed through informer Kirpal Singh
British arrested leaders before D-day
Some minor incidents but no major uprising
Date postponed but momentum lost
details.failure: British intelligence too strong; lack of coordination; some Indian soldiers loyal
details.significance: Most ambitious revolutionary conspiracy but complete failure

events.title: Defence of India Act
events.description: Draconian wartime law to crush revolutionary movement

points: Passed during World War I emergency
Provisions: Detention without trial, special tribunals, no jury trials
Provincial governments given extensive powers
Suspended normal legal rights
Used extensively against Ghadar revolutionaries
Thousands arrested and detained
Remained in force till 1919
details.significance: Crushed Ghadar movement; most repressive law till then

points: Series of trials under Defence of India Act
Over 300 accused in multiple batches
Charges: Waging war against King, conspiracy to mutiny
Trials held without jury in special tribunals
42 revolutionaries hanged
114 transported for life
93 imprisoned for varying terms
Many others detained without trial
notableMartyrs: Kartar Singh Sarabha (19 years old) - hanged Nov 16, 1915
details.significance: Decimated Ghadar movement; broke back of revolutionary terrorism

events.title: Hindu-German Conspiracy
events.description: Berlin Committee and Ghadar Party seek German support

points: Berlin Committee formed (1914) by Indian revolutionaries in Germany
Leaders: Virendranath Chattopadhyaya, Har Dayal, Bhupendranath Dutta
Coordinated with Ghadar Party in USA
German government provided some financial support and arms
Plans: Send arms to India, incite rebellion, coordinate with Afghanistan
Annie Larsen and Maverick ships sent with arms (intercepted)
Attempted to create mutiny among Indian POWs in Germany
Most plans failed due to British intelligence and naval blockade
details.significance: Showed international reach but ultimately futile; alienated some Indians

events.title: Silk Letter Conspiracy Exposed
events.description: Deobandi scholars' plan with Turkey and Afghanistan revealed

points: Leaders: Maulana Mahmud Hasan, Maulana Obaidullah Sindhi, Raja Mahendra Pratap
Plan: Provisional Government of India at Kabul (Dec 1, 1915)
Sought Turkish Caliph and Afghan Emir support for invasion of India
Communication via letters written on silk (to avoid detection)
British intelligence intercepted silk letters (1916)
Maulana Mahmud Hasan arrested in Mecca (on pilgrimage)
Imprisoned in Malta (1916-1920)
Plan completely foiled
details.significance: Showed even religious scholars involved in anti-British activities; Muslim participation in revolution

events.title: Annie Larsen Arms Shipment Failed
events.description: German arms ship intercepted by British

points: German government arranged arms shipment for Ghadar uprising
Ship: Annie Larsen (with arms) and SS Maverick (to transfer to India)
8,000 Springfield rifles, 3,000 pistols, ammunition
Plan: Transfer arms at sea, smuggle into India
Ships failed to meet at rendezvous
British intelligence tracked movements
Arms never reached India
Participants arrested in USA (San Francisco Hindu-German Conspiracy Trial, 1917-18)
details.significance: Showed German support but British naval supremacy prevented success

events.title: Rash Behari Bose Escapes to Japan
events.description: Revolutionary mastermind flees India, later leads INA in Japan

points: After failure of Ghadar uprising and British manhunt
Rash Behari Bose escaped to Japan (May 1915)
Lived in Japan for rest of life
Married Japanese woman, adopted Japanese name
Continued revolutionary activities from Japan
Later instrumental in forming Indian National Army (INA) in Southeast Asia
Handed over INA leadership to Subhash Chandra Bose (1943)
details.significance: Continued revolutionary tradition abroad; link to later INA movement

summary.title: Period Assessment
summary.overview: Revolutionary terrorism peaked 1908-1910, then shifted to international conspiracies during WWI (1914-1917). All major attempts crushed by British repression.
keyCharacteristics: Inspired by 1857 Revolt and international revolutionaries
legacy: Created revolutionary martyrs and nationalist consciousness
Forced British to take Indian aspirations seriously
Many revolutionaries later joined Gandhi's movement
INA in WWII had roots in this revolutionary tradition
